title-group.article-title: Classify patients with Moyamoya disease according to their cognitive performance might be helpful in clinical and practical with support vector machine based on hypergraph

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Moyamoya disease (MMD) patients were now classified according to their cerebrovascular manifestations, with cognition and emotion ignored, which attenuated the therapy. The present study tried to classify them based on their cognitive and emotional performance and explored the neural basis underlying this classification using resting‐state fMRI (rs‐fMRI). Thirty‐nine MMD patients were recruited, assessed mental function and MRI scanned. We adopted hierarchical analysis of their mental performance for new subtypes. Next, a three‐step analysis, with each step consisting of 10 random cross validation, was conducted for robust brain regions in classifying the three subtypes of patients in a support vector machine (SVM) model with hypergraph of rs‐fMRI. We found three new subtypes including high depression‐high anxiety‐low cognition (HE‐LC, 50%), low depression‐low anxiety‐high cognition (LE‐HC, 14%), and low depression‐low anxiety‐low cognition (LE‐LC, 36%), and no hemorrhagic MMD patients fell into the LE‐HC group. The temporal and the bilateral superior frontal cortex, and so forth were included in all 10 randomized SVM modeling. The classification accuracy of the final three‐way classification model was 67.5% in average of 10 random cross validation. In addition, the S value between the frontal cortex and the angular cortex was positively correlated with the anxiety score and backward digit span (p < .05). Our results might provide a new perspective for MMD classification concerning patients' mental status, guide timely surgery and suggest angular cortex, and so forth should be protected in surgery for cognitive consideration.

Different from traditional classification of Moyamoya disease (MMD) simply by clinical manifestations, we developed a new classification of MMD based on the cognitive function and built a support vector machine model with hypergraph of resting‐state fMRI for subtype classification.

Classify patients with Moyamoya disease according to their cognitive performance might be helpful in clinical and practical with support vector machine based on hypergraph. Human Brain Mapping, 44(6), 2407–2417. 10.1002/hbm.2621836799621PMC10028655

fn.p: Ying Wang and Nan Zhang are co‐first authors.

Funding information Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities, Grant/Award Number: WK9110000133; National Natural Science Foundation of China, Grant/Award Number: 82001794; Natural Science Foundation of Anhui Province, Grant/Award Number: 2008085QH380

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Moyamoya disease (MMD) is a type of relatively scarce cerebrovascular disease characterized by progressive occulsion or stenosis of the supraclinoid segment of internal carotid artery (ICA) and/or posterior cerebral artery, accompanied by formation of collateral vessels around the Willis circle in the skull base, mimicking sign of arising smoke in angiography (Suzuki & Takaku, 1969; Zhang et al., 2019). Given the ischemic nature of MMD and fragility of the smoky vessels, MMD patients are prone to suffer from cerebrovascular events (Yu et al., 2022). MMD is thus routinely classified into the following clinical subtypes including hemorrhagic, ischemic, and transient ischemic attack (TIA) types (Hirano et al., 2020; Unda et al., 2021).

In fact, except for the cerebrovascular symptoms, a few studies have reported that a relatively high portion of MMD patients, even those without apparent stroke lesions, also suffer from cognitive impairments such as executive dysfunction, memory decrease, attention deficits, and emotional dysfunction including depression and anxiety (Lei et al., 2017; Lei et al., 2020; Liu et al., 2019; Richards et al., 2019), regardless of which clinical type of MMD. In other words, current clinical classification neglects the cognitive and emotional status of patients, and thus there is a lack of effective guidance for the choice of treatment timing and prognostic value yet. In addition, various studies have proved that surgical revascularization at the early stage of MMD can help reverse the severity of cognitive impairment and emotional dysfunction (Ando et al., 2020; Kazumata et al., 2019; Lei et al., 2017; Yu et al., 2022). Therefore, a novel classification method based on cognitive and emotional status would be helpful for treatment and recovery. Patients with good cognitive performance might avoid cognitive decline and achieve better surgical results if they receive timely surgery.

The present study first explored a new classification of MMD patients based on patients' cognitive and emotional performance with hierarchical analysis. Afterward, efforts were made to find brain regions involved in classification models that robustly underlies the subtype differences. This classification model would also help with a quick clinical diagnosis and classification without extensive assessment of behavioral performance which relies on the cooperative capability of the patient and is time‐consuming. In clinical practice, it will be helpful in determining treatment strategy and adjuvant psychological and social interventions. Application of machine learning based on neuroimaging data in individualized classification might work (Cui et al., 2018; C. Feng, Zhu, et al., 2021). Recently, Lei et al. proposed a method of using dynamic resting‐state functional connectivity (FC) network to classify the pattern of cognitive impairment in MMD (Lei et al., 2020). However, it did not integrate the cognitive ability and emotional status and adopted the conventional FC method.

The conventional FC network is usually constructed based on the pairwise correlation among different brain regions (Agoalikum et al., 2021; Z. J. Feng, Deng, et al., 2021; Liu et al., 2022; Xu et al., 2021). However, we have reasons to believe that the connections between brain regions in real neural networks are intricate and not just pairwise (Jie et al., 2016). By contrast, in a hypergraph, a hyperedge can join any number of vertices, describes high‐order information of the real neural network, and therefore comprised more neurobiological implications and showed its effectiveness in diagnosis and classification of brain disorders (Jie et al., 2016) (Figure S1a).

As mentioned above, we intended to develop a machine‐learning model with hypergraph of functional networks, classifying the MMD patients into new subtypes based on the cognitive ability and emotional status. We hope that this study will be able to bring new perspective in understanding the cognitive and emotional impairment pattern of MMD, propose a quick identification and have significance in guiding the treatment paradigm of MMD patients.

sec.title: Subjects and procedure
sec.p: Fifty‐one MMD inpatients (21 females, 39.47 ± 10.07 years) in the First Affiliated Hospital of the University of Science and Technology of China received MRI screen (including 3d‐T1, resting‐state functional magnetic resonance imaging). Among them, 39 patients received both cognitive tests and assessment of depression and anxiety. The cognitive tests included Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) Test, forward digit span, backward digit span, and the Self‐Rating Anxiety/Depression Scale (SAS/SDS) was used for anxiety/depression assessment. In the present study, we focused on these 39 patients with complete data. They were clinically classified into hemorrhagic MMD, ischemic MMD, or TIA MMD.

All adult MMD patients with digital subtraction angiography at the department of neurosurgery of our hospital were enrolled between January 1, 2018 and December 31, 2021. The diagnostic criteria was according to the guideline published in 2012 (Research Committee on the Pathology and Treatment of Spontaneous Occlusion of the Circle of Willis; Health Labour Sciences Research Grant for Research on Measures for Infractable Diseases, 2012), those who meet the diagnostic criteria were included in the study. The exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) Younger than 18 years of age. (2) Patients secondary to metabolic, nutritional or infectious factors such as vitamin B deficiency, alcoholic brain injury, or hypothyroidism. (3) The presence of major psychopathology (psychopathy, major depression, substance abuse). (4) Neurological disorders affecting neuropsychological assessment, such as aphasia, hemianopia, and agnosia. (5) Patients with large volume of cerebral infarction or hemorrhagic lesion. Informed consent was obtained from all participants, and the study was approved by the Research Ethics Committee of the First Affiliated Hospital of the University of Science and Technology of China and conformed to the tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki.

sec.title: Clustering analysis
sec.p: Given age was a confounding factor impacting on cognitive function, we regressed age out of the MoCA score, the forward digit span, the backward digit span, the score of the SDS and the SRA scale. Afterward, we carried out the hierarchical analysis with R (x64 4.0.4). Each item was normalized to a variable with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1. Afterward, the Euclidean distance between each two subjects was calculated. Because the hierarchical analysis was more suitable for relatively small data set, we chose it to define the subtypes based on the Euclidean distance with the hclust () functions.

sec.title: Comparison of the behavioral data among new subtypes
sec.p: Based on the subtypes classified above, the behavioral data, including the MoCA score, the forward digit span, the backward digit span, the score of SDS and the SRA scale were compared among the groups of different subtypes with t‐test and box plotted with R.

sec.title: Attributes distribution on the subtypes
sec.p: We were interested in the distribution of the gender and clinical types (hemorrhagic MMD, ischemic MMD, or TIA MMD) within the new subtypes. Here, we presented it with stacked bar plot with R.

sec.title: MRI data acquisition
sec.p: Gradient echo‐planar magnetic resonance imaging data were obtained during the whole task procedure on the 3.0 T GE MR750 (United States) in the First Affiliated Hospital of the University of Science and Technology of China. Before entering the MRI scanner, all participants were told to keep their heads steady during all scans. A circularly polarized head coil was used, with foam padding to restrict head motion. Resting‐state functional MRI data with 243 frames were acquired with a T2*‐weighted echo‐planar imaging sequence (TE = 30 ms, TR = 2000 ms, FOV = 240 mm, matrix = 64 × 64, voxel size = 3.6 × 3.6 × 3.6 mm3, flip angle = 85°) with 33 axial slices (no gaps) covering the whole brain. Corresponding high‐resolution T1‐weighted three‐dimensional gradient‐echo (for stereotaxic transformation) images were also collected (TR = 1900 ms; TE = 2.26 ms; TI = 900 ms; 1 mm isotropic voxel; FOV = 250 mm).

sec.title: Data preprocessing
sec.p: Data preprocessing is performed using Analysis of Functional NeuroImages (AFNI) (afni.nimh.nih.gov, version AFNI_19.0.24, precompiled binary linux_ubuntu_16_64). As our previous study (Y. Wang et al., 2021), the afni_proc.py was a helpful tool that can be used to generate a single subject analysis “tcsh” script for fMRI data preanalysis. The resting‐state fMRI data of one patient was found incomplete and excluded (the resting‐state fMRI data of this patient only contains 176 TR). For all the other patients, we removed the first 3 frames and retained 240 frames for the following analysis. Initial processing included despiking, correction for temporal shifts between slices and head motion, alignment of echo planar imaging (EPI) to anatomy image and warpping to standard space (MNI 152), spatially smoothing with a Gaussian kernel (full width at half maximum = 4 mm), and temporal normalization. T1‐weighted images of individual subjects were aligned to the first frame of fMRI EPI data of resting scans and segmented into gray, white, and cerebrospinal fluid tissue classes using AFNI's “3dSeg” program. We based the criterion for censoring on the Euclidian norm of the first time differences of motion estimates ‖d‖2. It serves the function of eliminating data at time points when significant rapid motion is detected, excluding any volume with a frame wise‐dependent value exceeding 0.5 mm. Then we censored the motion frames and regressed the tissue‐based averages as bandpassing data (0.01–0.1 Hz) and regressed the motion parameters and derivatives. The resultant resting‐state fMRI data were then subjected to FC analysis. The brain space of fMRI scans for each subject was further parcellated into 90 regions of interest (ROIs) by warping the automated anatomical labeling (AAL) template (Tzourio‐Mazoyer et al., 2002) to the subject space. Considering that there are some other brain parcellation templates with more accurate brain region localization and network partition (e.g., Schaefer (Schaefer et al., 2018)), the present study also adopted the Schaefer template (7 networks, 100 parcellations) and carried out the same analysis again (please refer to the Supplementary Materials). The AAL naming system for brain regions is anatomically clear, therefore, it was chosen as the main results here. For each subject, the mean time series of each ROI was computed by averaging the nuisance signals‐regressed fMRI time series over all voxels in each ROI.

sec.title: The mathematical meaning of hypergraph and S matrix
sec.p: It is well known that graph is a powerful tool for representing relationship among the objects of interest, where each node in the graph denotes one object and each edge links nodes with certain type of relationship. In neuroimaging field, graph theory has been widely applied to the analysis of brain connectivity. In the conventional graph, an edge connects only two related nodes. The conventional graph only characterizes the pairwise relationships between paired nodes. However, in many applications, the relations among data should be more complex than pairwise ones (or the second‐order relations). Hypergraph has been proposed recently characterizing the high‐order relationships among multiple vertices, where each hyperedge can join any number of vertices (Figure S1a).

A hypergraph G = (V, E) is denoted by the vertex set V = {v 1, v 2, …, v
N }, the hyperedge set E = {e 1, e 2, …, e
m }. The basic structure of hypergraph G can be represented by the incidence matrix H=Hij∈RN×M with entriesHij=1,ifvi∈ej0,otherwise
When vi∈ej, that is, Hij=1, a hyperedge ej is said to be incident with a vertex vi.
Based on H, the hyperedge degree was defined byδej=∑viϵVHijfor1≤j≤M
V denotes that going through all the vertexes. Accordingly, let De denote the diagonal matrices for the hyperedge degrees, that is, De=diagδe1δe2…δeM∈RM×M.
Then, the similarity matrix of hypergraph G is defined byS=HDe−1HT∈RN×N

H
T is the transpose of H.

S can be viewed as the summation of the proportional weights over all hyperedges incident with both vertices vi and vj. Thus, the hypergraph similarity matrix S could explicitly reflect the high‐order relations among the vertices of hypergraph G (Xiao et al., 2020).

sec.title: Construction of connectivity hypernetwork
sec.p: We first extracted the mean time courses of the 90 ROIs according to the 90‐parcel AAL template and calculated the pair‐wised resting state FC for each subject (Pearson's correlation coefficient). And then went forward into the incidence matrix H stated as below. The algorithms were implemented in MATLAB (R2018b). Figure S1b showed the pipeline of the hypergraph and S matrix construction.

According to a recent work (Xiao et al., 2020), we first obtained H based on sparse linear regression (i.e., the Lasso) with the lasso function embed in the MATLAB and chose the coefficient with minimum 10‐fold cross validation error plus 1 SD. We constructed the connectivity hypernetworks from resting‐state fMRI time series using sparse representation. Specifically, denote X=x1…xm…xMT∈RM×d as one training subject with a total of M ROIs, where Xm represents the regional‐mean time series of the mth ROI, and d is the length of time series. Then, the regional mean time series of each ROI (i.e., x1) can be regarded as a response vector, and can be estimated by using a linear combination of time series of other M‐1 ROIs as follows:xm=Amαm+τm,m=1,2,…,M

Where Am=x1,…,xm−1,0,xm+1…,xM denotes a data matrix including all time series except the mth ROI (where we put a vector of all zeros in its location), am denotes the weight vector that quantifies the degree of influence of other ROIs to the mth ROI, and τm∈Rd denotes a noise term. Note that a zero element in the weight vector implies that the corresponding ROIs are insignificant in estimating the time series. After obtaining incidence matrix H, we can calculate the hyper graph similarity matrix S as a hypernetwork for a subject from the obtained H. S matrix was used as features of the SVM for subtype classification. From the hypergraph similarity matrix S of each patient, there were 4005 nonrepetitive nonzero ROI pairs based on the 90‐ROI parcellation. Considering the clustering analysis was based on the behavior data from which age was regressed out, hypergraph of functional networks was extremely likely related to the age. Therefore, age was first regressed out the hypergraph similarity matrix S (38 patients × 4005 ROI pairs) before SVM modeling. The SVM modeling was achieved by an integrated software in MATLAB (LIBSVM, a library for support vector machines, Software available at http://www.csie.ntu.edu.tw/cjlin/libsvm).

sec.title: Three steps analysis for classification SVM model
sec.p: In order to find brain regions that robustly underlies the subtype differences, with which constructed SVM classification models, a three‐step analysis was conducted, with each step consisting of 10 random allocations of training data set and test data set, and the analysis process is demonstrated in Figure 1.

Step 1: The purpose of the first step was for ROI pairs working stably in an SVM model regardless of allocation of data set (there were three SVM models, one for classifying high depression‐high anxiety‐low cognition group [HE‐LC] and low depression‐low anxiety‐high cognition group [LE‐HC], one for classifying HE‐LC and LE‐LC, and one for classifying LE‐HC and low depression‐low anxiety‐low cognition group [LE‐LC]). Take the SVM model for classifying HE‐LC and LE‐HC as example, there were only 23 subjects but 4005 ROI pairs, and therefore, to identify the most relevant features that can lead to a better generalization performance was extremely necessary (Guyon & Elisseeff, 2003). Here, it was achieved by the 10 random allocations of the 23 subjects into training data set (80%, 18 patients) and test data set (20%, 5 patients). After each random allocation, for the training data set (18 subjects × 4005 ROI pairs), we adopted linear kernel function and twofold cross validation mode of SVM. The group label (HE‐LC or LE‐HC) was the dependent variable (i.e., Y value), and the 4005 S value of ROI pairs were potential features of the SVM (i.e., X1,…,X4005). After the first SVM modeling with all 4005 features, the features were then sorted in ascending order referring to their absolute value of the coefficients. The feature with the minimum coefficient was removed and the remaining features went into the next SVM modeling. Like this, we removed features one by one. The minimum number of ROI pairs with 100% prediction accuracy within the training data set was obtained. Like this, after 10 random allocations, 10 groups of ROI pairs were obtained and the intersection of the 10 groups of ROI pairs was taken for the SVM model for classifying HE‐LC and LE‐HC.

Step 2: The second step was used to test the classification accuracy of randomly selected test data set by the SVM models with refined ROI pairs obtained from the first step. For each binary SVM model, take the SVM model for classifying HE‐LC and LE‐HC as example again, the 23 subjects were randomly allocated into training data set (80%, 18 patients) and test data set (20%, 5 patients). For the training data set (18 patients) with the refined ROI pairs, we adopted linear kernel function and twofold cross validation mode of SVM, and further tested the classification accuracy of the model in the test data set (8 patients). This random allocation was carried out 10 times and the average classification accuracy of the SVM model was obtained.

Step 3: SVM is a binary algorithm, and three models (model 1 for HE‐LC vs. LE‐HC, model 2 for HE‐LC vs. LE‐LC, model 3 for LE‐HC vs. LE‐LC) were needed to be combined for a quick clinical practice. For this, we randomly selected a test group (20% of all the 36 subjects, i.e., 8 subjects), and each patient from the test group would be predicted by the three models. Patients (e.g., from the HE‐LC) who were correctly identified by two models (models 1 and 2) would be considered as correctly classified. The classification accuracy of this test group would be calculated. And then such test group was randomly conducted 10 times and the averaged classification accuracy of the combined model was calculated.

sec.title: The relationship between the hypergraph and behavior
sec.p: We were also interested in how the hypergraph (S value of ROI‐pairs reserved in all three classification) was related to their behavior, including the SAS, SDS, forward digit span, backward digit span, and MoCA score, and therefore tried the Pearson correlation between the hypergraph and the behavioral performance.

sec.title: Identified subtypes and relation to clinical diagnoses
sec.p: As shown in Figure 2a, the novel ensemble clustering method identified three subtypes in the MMD sample (n = 36, two were extreme outliers), high depression‐high anxiety‐low cognition (HE‐LC, n = 18, 50%), low depression‐low anxiety‐high cognition (LE‐HC, n = 5, 14%), low depression‐low anxiety‐low cognition (lLE‐LC, n = 13, 36%). There was tiny change in the distribution of gender among the subtypes (47% females in HE‐LC, 40% females in LE‐HC, 54% females in LE‐LC). The distribution of clinical diagnosis (TIA, ischemic, and hemorrhagic MMD) varied between the three groups. No hemorrhagic patient was found in the LE‐HC, who exhibit high cognition (better forward digit span, better backward digit span, and better MoCA score) (Figure 2b).

caption.p: The establishment of classification support vector machine (SVM) model was divided into three steps, each step consisting of 10 randomizations of training data set and test data set. Step 1 was for robust region of interest (ROI) pairs in modeling. Step 2 was for independent test of classification accuracy of SVM model 1, model 2, and model 3. Step 3 was for the independent test of classification accuracy of a subject with the combined models

sec.p: The cognitive function difference between the clusters is shown in Figure 3. For age, there was no significant difference among the three clusters. For the SAS, HE‐LC was significantly higher than LE‐HC (t = 2.68, p < .05), and LE‐HC significantly higher than LE‐LC (t = 3.72, p < .01). For SDS, HE‐LC was significantly higher than LE‐HC (t = 3.92, p < .05), and LE‐HC was not different from LE‐LC (t = 0.66, p > .5). For forward digit span, HE‐LC was significantly lower than LE‐HC (t = −2.41, p < .05), and LE‐HC was also significantly higher than LE‐LC (t = 2.90, p < .05). For backward digit span, HE‐LC was significantly lower than LE‐HC (t = −4.26, p < .01), and LE‐HC was also significantly higher than LE‐LC (t = 3.67, p < .01). For MoCA score, HE‐LC was significantly lower than LE‐HC (t = −4.55, p < .001), and LE‐HC was also significantly higher than LE‐LC (t = 6.73, p < .001) (Figure 3).

caption.p: New subtypes and related characteristics difference and distribution. (a) The novel ensemble clustering method identified three subtypes in the Moyamoya disease (MMD) sample. The horizontal axis denotes each patient. (b) Distribution of gender and clinical diagnosis in the new subtypes. The horizontal axis denotes each group and the vertical axis denotes the number of patients

Differences of age, Self‐Rating Anxiety (SAS), Self‐Rating Depression Scale (SDS), forward digit, backward digit and Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) score among the new subtypes (*, p < .05; **, p < .005; ***, p < .0005). The horizontal axis denotes each group and the vertical axis denotes the age and the scores

sec.title: ROIs of each binary SVM and classification accuracy
sec.p: For each binary SVM classification, there were the 10 randomizations. ROI pairs reserved in each randomization were taken the intersection as the final feature ROI pairs of the binary SVM classification. For model 1 (HE‐LC vs. LE‐HC), ROI pairs only included the “Precentral_L” and the “Frontal_Mid_L” (Table 1), and the averaged classification accuracy of such ROI pair in the next 10 independent test classification was 82%. For model 2 (HE‐LC vs. LE‐LC), ROI pairs included the “Frontal_Mid_R” and the “Angular_R,” and so forth (Table 2), and the averaged classification accuracy of such ROI pair in the next 10 independent test classification was 73.33%. For model 3 (LE‐HC vs. LE‐LC), ROI pairs included the “Frontal_Sup_L” and the “Angular_L,” and so forth (Table 3), and the averaged classification accuracy of such ROI pair in the next 10 independent test classification was 77.75%.

caption.p: ROI pairs of model 1 of classification between HE‐LC and LE‐HC

fn.p: Abbreviations: HE‐LC, high depression‐high anxiety‐low cognition; LE‐HC, low depression‐low anxiety‐high cognition; ROI, region of interest.

caption.p: ROI pairs of model 2 of classification between HE‐LC and LE‐LC

fn.p: Abbreviations: HE‐LC, high depression‐high anxiety‐low cognition; LE‐HC, low depression‐low anxiety‐high cognition; ROI, region of interest.

caption.p: ROI pairs of model 3 of classification between LE‐HC and LE‐LC

fn.p: Abbreviations: HE‐LC, high depression‐high anxiety‐low cognition; LE‐HC, low depression‐low anxiety‐high cognition; ROI, region of interest.

sec.p: The result with Schaefer template (7 network 100 parcellations) was shown in the Supplementary Materials 1.1 and Supplementary Tables 1 and 3.

sec.title: The classification of the combined three‐way SVM model
sec.p: We randomly selected 8 patients (20% out of the 36 subjects) as a test data set. Each of them (take a subject was belonged to the HE‐LC) was successively classified by the model 1 (HE‐LC vs. LE‐HC), model 2 (HE‐LC vs. LE‐LC), and model 3 (LE‐HC vs. LE‐LC). Those who were correctly identified by two models (models 1 and 2) could be considered as the correctly identified, and the classification accuracy of the three‐way SVM model within each randomly selected test data set was calculated. And the averaged classification accuracy of the 10 randomization was 67.5%. The result with Schaefer template (7 network 100 parcellations) was shown in the Supplementary Materials 1.2.

sec.title: Classification and hypergraph visualization
sec.p: Hypergraph of models 1–3 were visualized with the BrainNet Viewer (Xia et al., 2013, http://www.nitrc.org/projects/bnv/) in axial view (Figure 4). The ROI pairs of the models are shown in the Tables 1, 2, 3.

caption.p: Hypergraph was visualized with the BrainNet Viewer (Xia et al., 2013, http://www.nitrc.org/projects/bnv/) in axial view: (a) model 1; (b) model 2; and (c) model 3

sec.title: The relationship between the S value of ROI pairs and the behavioral data
sec.p: S value between the “Frontal_Mid_R” and the “Angular_R” was positively correlated with the SAS score (r = .49, p < .005). S value between the “Frontal_Sup_L” and the “Angular_L” was positively correlated with the backward digit span (r = .41, p < .05) (Figure 5).

caption.p: S value between the “Frontal_Mid_R” and the “Angular_R” was positively correlated with the Self‐Rating Anxiety (SAS) score (r = .49, p < .005). S value between the “Frontal_Sup_L” and the “Angular_L” was positively correlated with the backward digit span (r = .41, p < .05). The horizontal axis denotes S value between the brain regions, and the vertical axis denotes the SAS score and backward digit span

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: In this article, we proposed a new classification of MMD by using the data‐driven clustering analysis, based on the data of extensive emotional and cognitive assessment. In the newly‐established classification method focusing on emotional and cognitive impairment of MMD patients, three subtypes, HE‐LC, LE‐HC, and LE‐LC, were identified. Furthermore, a machine‐learning SVM model was established to predict the MMD subtype according to the hypergraph of resting‐state fMRI, which achieved high accuracy and specificity. Finally, the relationship between the S value of ROI pairs identified in the prediction models and the behavioral data was calculated, which will be of great help in understanding the neurological mechanism of emotional and cognitive impairment in MMD patients.

sec.title: New classification of MMD subtypes
sec.p: In recent years, emotional and cognitive impairments in MMD patients are attracting more and more attention (Ando et al., 2020; Kazumata et al., 2019; Lei et al., 2017; Lei et al., 2020; Liu et al., 2019; Richards et al., 2019). MMD patients belong to different clinical subtypes may suffer from the same type of cognitive or emotional dysfunction. One MMD patient may suffer from more than one type of cognitive or emotional impairment. However, the characteristics of cognitive and emotional impairment in MMD patients are unclear; we still lack a widely accepted classification method that integrates the cognitive and emotional status of MMD patients. Once such method is established, it will be of great practical value in determining the strategy and optimal time window for treatment.

This new classification was established based on a data‐driven clustering analysis. According to the extensive emotional and cognitive assessment result, three subtypes can be identified, including HE‐LC, LE‐HC, and LE‐LC. The characteristics of the distribution of these subtypes in the traditional clinical subtypes can be summarized as follows. First, all the hemorrhagic MMD patients belong to the lower cognition groups, including HE‐LC LE‐LC, whereas the LE‐HC only include the ischemic and TIA MMD patients. Such phenomenon is in concordance with the clinical practice that the hemorrhagic MMD patients are usually with more severe cognitive impairments. Second, majority of the ischemic MMD patients belong to the lower cognition group, which indicates that emotional and cognitive disorder is prevalent in ischemic MMD patients. Third, all the TIA and part of ischemic MMD patients fall on the low depression‐low anxiety‐high cognition group (LE‐HC), which accounts of 14% of all the MMD patients in this cohort. Such result demonstrates that only a small part of MMD patients have relatively intact emotional and cognitive status. For such type of patients, early surgical intervention might decrease or avoid the deterioration of emotional or cognitive impairment. However, the effect of surgical intervention on the MMD patients with mild or intact emotional and cognitive status is still unclear, which calls for further clinical trials to elucidate the problem. Fourthly, part of hemorrhagic and ischemic MMD patients fall on HE‐LC, while part of hemorrhagic and ischemic MMD patients fall on LE‐LC. Such result demonstrates that even in MMD patients with cognitive impairment, the degree of emotional disorder is different, which indicates that the emotional disorder in MMD patients should not be ignored. Further study regarding the mechanism and interventional maneuvers of emotional disorder in MMD patients should be performed.

sec.title: Prediction of the new MMD subtype based on hypergraph
sec.p: Since the new classification method of MMD patients has been established, a practical problem can be proposed that whether the integrated cognitive and emotional subtype can be predicted simply according to the neuroimaging data. If so, the time‐consuming and cooperation‐needed emotional and cognitive assessments can be simplified or avoided, at least in the patients with low educational‐level who cannot cooperate well with the assessment, in the clinical practice. Similarly, subjective cognitive decline (SCD) is a preclinical asymptomatic stage of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Accurate diagnosis of SCD represents the greatest challenge for current clinical practice (Lin et al., 2022). Furthermore, the prediction can be taken as a method of screening. Specifically, if the patient is predicted to fall in the classification with emotional or cognitive impairment based on the neuroimaging data, extensive behavioral assessment should be performed to detailedly evaluate the emotional and cognitive status, which is taken as the reference for the determination of treatment strategy and for the dynamic evaluation of treatment effect.

Convergent evidences have corroborated that various kinds of neurological and psychiatric diseases are with brain network disturbances rather than focal changes (Lassalle‐Lagadec et al., 2012; Sporns, 2014; Z. Wang et al., 2015). As an important way of depicting the network property both globally and locally, graph theory has been widely applied in various kinds of neurological and psychiatric diseases, especially regarding the cognitive and emotional perspectives, for elucidating the mechanism of the disorders or for predicting behavioral performance (Bassett & Mattar, 2017; Bassett & Sporns, 2017; Petersen & Sporns, 2015). In comparison with the conventional graph theory analysis, in which the edge is defined as the correlation between only two nodes, the newly proposed concept of hypergraph is characterized as the high‐order relationships among multiple vertices, where each hyperedge can join any number of vertices. For this advantage, hypergraph is considered to be able to demonstrate more biological meaning of the brain network and has illustrated the clinical effectiveness in diagnosis and classification of neurological diseases.

In fact, a number of studies have reported the application of machine‐learning method in classifying or predicting the neurocognitive performance in healthy subjects and patients with neurological diseases. For example, a recent study indicates that multimodal MRI imaging combining with SVM yields excellent and powerful performances at categorizing SCD due to AD, suggesting potential for clinical utility (Lin et al., 2022). In this article, the power of SVM model in classifying MMD patients based on functional neuroimaging data has also been demonstrated.

Except for classifying new subtype of MMD patients, the SVM model based on hypergraph pattern also help in unravelling the possible neurological mechanism of emotional and cognitive impairment of MMD patients. As illustrated in Tables 1, 2, 3, the ROI pairs that differentiate the MMD subtypes in the SVM models were mainly located in the bilateral perisylvian areas including frontal, temporal and parietal lobes. Furthermore, the anxiety score was positively correlated with the S value between the right middle frontal gyrus and the right angular gyrus. The backward digit span was positively correlated with the S value between the left superior frontal gyrus and the left angular gyrus. These perisylvian areas are closely related to high‐order cognitive and emotional function. From surgical perspective, these areas are located in or adjacent to the areas suffering reduced blood supply following the formation of stenosis of ICA, and undergoing surgical revascularization. In conclusion, this study provides a new choice in diagnosis and prognosis prediction of MMD patients, and probably indicates protection of the brain regions and connection that were related to cognitive and emotional function in surgery.

sec.title: AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS
sec.p: Ying Wang, Nan Zhang, and Chengyu Xia designed the study, analyzed the data, interpreted the data, and contributed to article writing. Nan Li analyzed the data and contributed to the data interpretation. Sheng Qian, Jian Liu, and Shaojie Yu contributed to data collection.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST
sec.p: The authors declare no competing financial conflicts of interest to disclose.

ack.p: The authors thank all the study participants for their support to their research.

sec.p: Data are available upon request from the corresponding author.
